column2: Angels & Demons (Robert Langdon  #1)
column13: |CERN director Maximilian Kohler discovers one of the facility's top physicists
column14: Leonardo Vetra
column15: murdered
column16: his chest branded with an ambigram of the word "Illuminati." Kohler contacts Robert Langdon
column17: an expert on symbology
column18: who determines that the ambigram is authentic. Kohler calls Vetra's adopted daughter Vittoria home and it is ascertained that the Illuminati
column19: an ancient anti-religious organization thought extinct
column20: have stolen a canister containing antimatter
column21: a substance with destructive potential comparable to a nuclear weapon. When at CERN
column22: the canister is stored in a unique electrical charger which ensures the antimatter's stability
column23: but when removed
column24: its backup battery provides power for 24 hours
column25: after which the antimatter would fall out of suspension and
column26: on coming into contact with the physical matter of the container
column27: explode. The canister is located somewhere in Vatican City
column28: with a security camera in front of it
column29: as its digital clock counts down to an explosion due to occur at midnight
column30: which will wipe out the Vatican.

column1: Langdon is initially convinced that the Illuminati cannot be responsible for two reasons: 1) the Illuminati went extinct centuries ago
column2: and their remnants were absorbed into the Freemasons and 2) the Illuminati
column4: would never sanction the murder of a fellow scientist. Kohler explains that Vetra might be an exception
column5: as he was also an ordained Catholic priest.

column1: Langdon and Vittoria make their way to Vatican City
column2: where the Pope has recently died. They are told that the four Preferiti
column3: the cardinals who are most likely to be elected pope
column4: are missing. Langdon and Vittoria search for the preferiti in hopes that they will also find the antimatter canister. Their search is assisted by Camerlengo Carlo Ventresca (the late pope's closest aide)
column5: the Vatican's Swiss Guard and Commander Olivetti.

column1: Langdon tells Vittoria how the Illuminati created a citywide map known as the "Path of Illumination
column2:
a trail once used by the Illuminati as a means of inducting new members; aspirants who wanted to join the Illuminati were required to follow a series of subtle clues left in various churches in and around Rome. The clues indicate the secret meeting place of the Illuminati. Langdon's theory is that the Path was marked by sculptures created by a mysterious Illuminati artist: an Illuminati member placed as a mole within the Vatican itself. Langdon is granted access to the Vatican Archives by the camerlengo, where he believes a document containing the clues to the Path of Illumination is located. The clues to the Illuminati markers are placed inside Galileo's famous book called 'Diagramma.' Langdon then sets off on the Path of Illumination in hopes of saving the preferiti and recovering the antimatter canister.

The Path leads Langdon and Vittoria to four churches in Rome, each one containing works of art by Baroque artist Gian Lorenzo Bernini (who Langdon realizes is the Illuminati artist) depicting angels and associated with one of the primordial elements: Earth, Air, Fire and Water. Langdon realizes the four preferiti will be murdered in a way thematically related to each location's related element. The first cardinal is branded with an Earth ambigram and has soil forced down his throat, suffocating him; the second is branded with an Air ambigram and has his lungs punctured; the third is branded with a Fire ambigram and is burned alive; and the fourth is branded with a Water ambigram and is wrapped in chains and left to drown at the bottom of a fountain.
During their search for the Illuminati lair, Langdon and Vittoria are seen getting closer.

After finding the bodies of the first two preferiti, Langdon hurries to the Santa Maria della Victoria Basilica and finds the preferiti's abductor in the act of setting the third cardinal on fire. The kidnapper is an unnamed assassin who is working under the orders of the Illuminati master Janus
column3:
whose true identity is unknown. Commander Olivetti is killed and the assassin kidnaps Vittoria. Langdon escapes and accosts the assassin at the final element's marker (Water) but he is unable to save the cardinal.

Langdon must complete the Path of Illumination in order to find the assassin and rescue Vittoria. His search leads him to Castel Sant'Angelo which he realizes is the Church of Illumination
column4:
the Illuminati's secret lair. Under the papal fortress is a tunnel which leads directly into the pope's private library in the Vatican. Langdon frees Vittoria and together they send the assassin falling several hundred feet to his death. The two hurry back to St. Peter's Basilica, where they find that Kohler has arrived to confront the camerlengo in private. Langdon and Vittoria fear that Kohler is Janus and that he has come to murder the camerlengo. Hearing the camerlengo scream in agony from being branded with the Illuminati Diamond (a symbol combining all four Illuminati ambigrams), the Swiss Guards burst into the room and open fire on Kohler. Just before he dies, Kohler gives Langdon a mini video camera containing a video Kohler made while confronting the camerlengo and tells him to give it to the media.

With time running out, the Swiss Guard evacuates the Basilica. The camerlengo rushes back in, claiming that he has received a vision from God, who has revealed the location of the antimatter canister to him. With Langdon in pursuit, the camerlengo ventures into the catacombs and finds the canister sitting atop the tomb of Saint Peter. Langdon and the camerlengo retrieve the antimatter and get in a helicopter with only minutes to spare. The camerlengo manages to parachute safely onto the roof of St. Peter's just as the canister explodes harmlessly in the sky. The crowd in St. Peter's Square look in awe as the camerlengo stands triumphantly before them. Because of this miracle
column5:
the cardinals debate whether to elect the camerlengo as the new Pope. Langdon manages to survive the explosion using a window cover from the helicopter as a parachute, a trick he learned while touring CERN with Maximillian Kohler and lands in the Tiber River.
As Langdon regains consciousness, he finds himself in a hospital located on an island. He is given the video camera which he placed in the pocket of his tweed jacket. He is shocked when he hears the footage and becomes desperate to head back to the Vatican. The video shows the camerlengo branding himself with the Illuminati diamond and confessing that he himself is Janus, and who set in motion the night's chain of events in order to sabotage the Vatican. He also confesses that he killed the Pope with an overdose of heparin, a powerful anticoagulant because the Pope revealed he had fathered a child.
After viewing Kohler's tape, Langdon, Vittoria, and the cardinals confront the camerlengo. Shortly before the novel began, the Pope met with Leonardo Vetra, who believed that antimatter was capable of establishing a link between science and God. Vetra's beliefs caused great discomfort to the camerlengo. While discussing Vetra, the pope revealed that his support was caused by science having given him a son. Without waiting to hear the explanation (that the child was the result of artificial insemination) and horrified that the Pope appeared to have broken his vow of chastity, the camerlengo plotted to rectify the situation. He poisoned the pope and, under the guise of an Illuminati master (Janus), recruited the assassin to kill Vetra, steal the antimatter and kidnap and murder the preferiti. The camerlengo planted the antimatter in St. Peter's Basilica, feigned his last-minute vision from God, and retrieved the canister just in time to save the Vatican from the ensuing explosion, hoping to unite the struggling Catholic Church. The Illuminati involvement was merely a plot engineered by the camerlengo to cover his own involvement.
Upon the discovery and the camerlengo's attempts to justify his murder of the Pope, Cardinal Saverio Mortati, Dean of the College of Cardinals, reveals that the camerlengo is, in fact, the late pope's biological son, conceived with a nun through artificial insemination. Overcome with guilt, Ventresca soaks himself in oil and sets himself on fire before a crowd of onlookers in St. Peter's Square. His ashes are recovered by Mortati, who places them in an urn which is placed inside his father's sarcophagus. It is revealed that the cardinals' endorsing of him would have made him Pope by acclamation. Mortati is unanimously elected pope by the cardinals, and Langdon and Vittoria reunite at Hotel Bernini. The last brand, the Illuminati Diamond, is given to Langdon on indefinite loan, provided that he return it to the Vatican in his will.|
968,The Da Vinci Code (Robert Langdon  #2),Dan Brown,3.84,0307277674,9780307277671,eng,489,1679706,35877,3/28/2006,Anchor,|Louvre curator and Priory of Sion grand master Jacques Saunière is fatally shot one night at the museum by an albino Catholic monk named Silas, who is working on behalf of someone he knows only as the Teacher, who wishes to discover the location of the keystone
column6:
an item crucial in the search for the Holy Grail. 
After Saunière's body is discovered in the pose of the Vitruvian Man by Leonardo da Vinci, the police summon Harvard professor Robert Langdon, who is in town on business. Police captain Bezu Fache tells him that he was summoned to help the police decode the cryptic message Saunière left during the final minutes of his life. The message includes a Fibonacci sequence out of order and an anagram 'O, draconian devil Oh, lame saint'.
Langdon explains to Fache that Saunière was a leading authority on the subject of goddess artwork and that the pentacle Saunière drew on his chest in his own blood represents an allusion to the goddess and not devil worship, as Fache believes.
Sophie Neveu, a police cryptographer, secretly explains to Langdon that she is Saunière's estranged granddaughter, and that Fache thinks Langdon is the murderer because the last line in her grandfather's message, which was meant for Neveu, said P.S. Find Robert Langdon
column7: which Fache had erased prior to Langdon's arrival.  However, P.S." does not refer to "postscript"
column8: but rather to Sophie — the nickname given to her by her grandfather was "Princess Sophie".  Neveu is troubled by memories of her grandfather's involvement in a secret pagan group. However
column9: she understands that her grandfather intended Langdon to decipher the code
column10: which leads to da Vinci's Mona Lisa
column11: which in turn leads to his painting Madonna of the Rocks. They find a pendant which holds the address of the Paris branch of the Depository Bank of Zurich.

column1: Neveu and Langdon escape from the police and visit the bank. In the safe deposit box they find a box containing the keystone: a cryptex
column2: a cylindrical
column4: rotating dials labeled with letters. When these are lined up correctly
column5: they unlock the device. If the cryptex is forced open
column6: an enclosed vial of vinegar breaks and dissolves the message inside the cryptex
column7: which was written on papyrus. The box containing the cryptex contains clues to its password.

column1: Langdon and Neveu take the keystone to the home of Langdon's friend
column2: Sir Leigh Teabing
column3: an expert on the Holy Grail
column4: the legend of which is heavily connected to the Priory. There
column5: Teabing explains that the Grail is not a cup
column6: but connected to Mary Magdalene and Royal blood.

column1: The trio then flees the country on Teabing's private plane
column2: on which they conclude that the proper combination of letters spell out Neveu's given name
column4: they discover a smaller cryptex inside it
column5: along with another riddle that ultimately leads the group to the tomb of Isaac Newton in Westminster Abbey.

column1: During the flight to Britain
column2: Neveu reveals the source of her estrangement from her grandfather ten years earlier: arriving home unexpectedly from university
column3: Neveu secretly witnessed a spring fertility rite conducted in the secret basement of her grandfather's country estate. From her hiding place
column4: she was shocked to see her grandfather with a woman at the center of a ritual attended by men and women who were wearing masks and chanting praise to the goddess. She fled the house and broke off all contact with Saunière. Langdon explains that what she witnessed was an ancient ceremony known as hieros gamos or "sacred marriage."

column1: By the time they arrive at Westminster Abbey
column2: Teabing is revealed to be the Teacher for whom Silas is working. Teabing wishes to use the Holy Grail
column3: which he believes is a series of documents establishing that Jesus Christ married Mary Magdalene and bore children
column4: in order to ruin the Vatican. He compels Langdon at gunpoint to solve the second cryptex's password
column5: which Langdon realizes is "apple." Langdon secretly opens the cryptex and removes its contents before tossing the empty cryptex in the air.

column1: Teabing is arrested by Fache
column2: who by now realizes that Langdon is innocent. Bishop Aringarosa
column3: head of religious sect Opus Dei and Silas' mentor
column4: realizing that Silas has been used to murder innocent people
column5: rushes to help the police find him. When the police find Silas hiding in an Opus Dei Center
column6: he assumes that they are there to kill him and he rushes out
column7: accidentally shooting Bishop Aringarosa. Bishop Aringarosa survives but is informed that Silas was found dead later from a gunshot wound.

column1: The final message inside the second keystone leads Neveu and Langdon to Rosslyn Chapel
column2: whose docent turns out to be Neveu's long-lost brother
column3: whom Neveu had been told died as a child in the car accident that killed her parents. The guardian of Rosslyn Chapel
column4: Marie Chauvel Saint Clair
column5: is Neveu's long-lost grandmother. It is revealed that Neveu and her brother are descendants of Merovingian bloodline. The Priory of Sion hid her identity to protect her from possible threats to her life.

column1: The real meaning of the last message is that the Grail is buried beneath the small pyramid directly below the La Pyramide Inversée
column2: the inverted glass pyramid of the Louvre. It also lies beneath the "Rose Line
column3: an allusion to Rosslyn." Langdon figures out this final piece to the puzzle; he follows the Rose Line to La Pyramide Inversée
column4: where he kneels to pray before the hidden sarcophagus of Mary Magdalene
column5: as the Templar knights did before him.|

After Saunière's body is discovered in the pose of the Vitruvian Man by Leonardo da Vinci, the police summon Harvard professor Robert Langdon, who is in town on business. Police captain Bezu Fache tells him that he was summoned to help the police decode the cryptic message Saunière left during the final minutes of his life. The message includes a Fibonacci sequence out of order and an anagram 'O, draconian devil Oh, lame saint'.
Langdon explains to Fache that Saunière was a leading authority on the subject of goddess artwork and that the pentacle Saunière drew on his chest in his own blood represents an allusion to the goddess and not devil worship, as Fache believes.
Sophie Neveu, a police cryptographer, secretly explains to Langdon that she is Saunière's estranged granddaughter, and that Fache thinks Langdon is the murderer because the last line in her grandfather's message, which was meant for Neveu, said P.S. Find Robert Langdon
column17: which Fache had erased prior to Langdon's arrival.  However, P.S." does not refer to "postscript"
column18: but rather to Sophie — the nickname given to her by her grandfather was "Princess Sophie".  Neveu is troubled by memories of her grandfather's involvement in a secret pagan group. However
column19: she understands that her grandfather intended Langdon to decipher the code
column20: which leads to da Vinci's Mona Lisa
column21: which in turn leads to his painting Madonna of the Rocks. They find a pendant which holds the address of the Paris branch of the Depository Bank of Zurich.

column1: Neveu and Langdon escape from the police and visit the bank. In the safe deposit box they find a box containing the keystone: a cryptex
column2: a cylindrical
column4: rotating dials labeled with letters. When these are lined up correctly
column5: they unlock the device. If the cryptex is forced open
column6: an enclosed vial of vinegar breaks and dissolves the message inside the cryptex
column7: which was written on papyrus. The box containing the cryptex contains clues to its password.

column1: Langdon and Neveu take the keystone to the home of Langdon's friend
column2: Sir Leigh Teabing
column3: an expert on the Holy Grail
column4: the legend of which is heavily connected to the Priory. There
column5: Teabing explains that the Grail is not a cup
column6: but connected to Mary Magdalene and Royal blood.

column1: The trio then flees the country on Teabing's private plane
column2: on which they conclude that the proper combination of letters spell out Neveu's given name
column4: they discover a smaller cryptex inside it
column5: along with another riddle that ultimately leads the group to the tomb of Isaac Newton in Westminster Abbey.

column1: During the flight to Britain
column2: Neveu reveals the source of her estrangement from her grandfather ten years earlier: arriving home unexpectedly from university
column3: Neveu secretly witnessed a spring fertility rite conducted in the secret basement of her grandfather's country estate. From her hiding place
column4: she was shocked to see her grandfather with a woman at the center of a ritual attended by men and women who were wearing masks and chanting praise to the goddess. She fled the house and broke off all contact with Saunière. Langdon explains that what she witnessed was an ancient ceremony known as hieros gamos or "sacred marriage."

column1: By the time they arrive at Westminster Abbey
column2: Teabing is revealed to be the Teacher for whom Silas is working. Teabing wishes to use the Holy Grail
column3: which he believes is a series of documents establishing that Jesus Christ married Mary Magdalene and bore children
column4: in order to ruin the Vatican. He compels Langdon at gunpoint to solve the second cryptex's password
column5: which Langdon realizes is "apple." Langdon secretly opens the cryptex and removes its contents before tossing the empty cryptex in the air.

column1: Teabing is arrested by Fache
column2: who by now realizes that Langdon is innocent. Bishop Aringarosa
column3: head of religious sect Opus Dei and Silas' mentor
column4: realizing that Silas has been used to murder innocent people
column5: rushes to help the police find him. When the police find Silas hiding in an Opus Dei Center
column6: he assumes that they are there to kill him and he rushes out
column7: accidentally shooting Bishop Aringarosa. Bishop Aringarosa survives but is informed that Silas was found dead later from a gunshot wound.

column1: The final message inside the second keystone leads Neveu and Langdon to Rosslyn Chapel
column2: whose docent turns out to be Neveu's long-lost brother
column3: whom Neveu had been told died as a child in the car accident that killed her parents. The guardian of Rosslyn Chapel
column4: Marie Chauvel Saint Clair
column5: is Neveu's long-lost grandmother. It is revealed that Neveu and her brother are descendants of Merovingian bloodline. The Priory of Sion hid her identity to protect her from possible threats to her life.

column1: The real meaning of the last message is that the Grail is buried beneath the small pyramid directly below the La Pyramide Inversée
column2: the inverted glass pyramid of the Louvre. It also lies beneath the "Rose Line
column3: an allusion to Rosslyn." Langdon figures out this final piece to the puzzle; he follows the Rose Line to La Pyramide Inversée
column4: where he kneels to pray before the hidden sarcophagus of Mary Magdalene
column5: as the Templar knights did before him.|

column2: Deception Point
column13: |On the eve of a United States presidential election
column14: NASA discovers a meteorite in the Milne Ice Shelf containing an insect-like creature
column15: seemingly proving the existence of extraterrestrial life. The discovery could potentially be a deciding factor in the presidential election
column16: in which one of the key issues is whether to continue funding NASA. Incumbent US President Zachary Herney favors supporting space research
column17: while his challenger Senator Sedgewick Sexton argues for dissolving NASA.

column1: President Herney sends a team of experts to the Arctic to verify the authenticity of the extraterrestrial insect: oceanographer Michael Tolland
column2: astrophysicist Corky Marlinson
column4: paleontologist Wailee Ming
column5: and National Reconnaissance Office employee Rachel Sexton
column6: Senator Sexton's daughter.

column1: When the scientists find an anomaly that calls the authenticity of NASA's discovery into question
column2: they're attacked by a Delta Force team that had secretly been spying on them. The Delta Force soldiers kill Ming and Mangor while leaving Rachel
column3: Tolland and Marlinson to perish on an ice floe
column4: but they're rescued by the Navy submarine USS Charlotte. Rachel alerts presidential advisor Marjorie Tench and NRO director William Pickering of the attack
column5: and Pickering sends an air transport to bring them back to the United States.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: in Washington
column4: Tench tries to sabotage Sexton's campaign by blackmailing his aide Gabrielle Ashe with photos of an extramarital affair that she had with Senator Sexton
column5: and reveals that Sexton is secretly backed by a coalition of private aerospace corporations who would profit from NASA's dissolution. Ashe discovers that Tench's claims are true
column6: but also finds out that NASA lied about the origin of the meteorite.

column1: The surviving scientists retreat to Tolland's research ship off the New Jersey coast
column2: where they fully re-analyze their data and discover that the meteorite is fake. A surprise attack by the Delta Force team prompts Rachel to fax the data to her father
column3: asking for help. In the ensuing skirmish
column4: all Delta Force soldiers are killed
column5: their helicopter is sunk
column6: and Pickering is revealed to be their commander. Pickering reveals that he masterminded the fake meteorite to hurt Herney's campaign. The ship and Pickering are sucked in by a vortex
column7: while a Coast Guard Osprey picks up Rachel
column8: Tolland and Marlinson.

column1: Sexton attempts to reveal Rachel's fax in a press conference in hopes of implicating NASA and the president in the meteorite hoax
column2: but Rachel and Gabrielle swap Rachel's fax with the photo evidence of Sexton's affair with Gabrielle
column3: humiliating him and ruining his chances of winning the election. By the end of the story
column4: Michael and Rachel have developed a romantic relationship.|

column2: The Good Earth (House of Earth  #1)
column13: |The story begins on Wang Lung's wedding day and follows the rise and fall of his fortunes. The House of Hwang
column14: a family of wealthy landowners
column15: lives in the nearby town
column16: where Wang Lung's future wife
column17: O-Lan
column18: lives as a slave. However
column19: the House of Hwang slowly declines due to opium use
column20: frequent spending
column21: uncontrolled borrowing and a general unwillingness to work.

column1: Following the marriage of Wang Lung and O-Lan
column2: both work hard on their farm and slowly save enough money to buy one plot of land at a time from the Hwang family. O-Lan delivers three sons and three daughters; the first daughter becomes mentally handicapped as a result of severe malnutrition brought on by famine. Her father greatly pities her and calls her "Poor Fool"
column3: a name by which she is addressed throughout her life. O-Lan kills her second daughter at birth to spare her the misery of growing up in such hard times
column4: and to give the remaining family a better chance to survive.

column1: During the devastating famine and drought
column2: the family must flee to a large city in the south to find work. Wang Lung's malevolent uncle offers to buy his possessions and land
column3: but for significantly less than their value. The family sells everything except the land and the house. Wang Lung then faces the long journey south
column4: contemplating how the family will survive walking
column5: when he discovers that the "firewagon" (the Chinese word for the newly built train) takes people south for a fee.

column1: In the city
column2: O-Lan and the children beg while Wang Lung pulls a rickshaw. Wang Lung's father begs but does not earn any money
column3: and sits looking at the city instead. They find themselves aliens among their more metropolitan countrymen who look different and speak in a fast accent. They no longer starve
column4: due to the one-cent charitable meals of congee
column5: but still live in abject poverty. Wang Lung longs to return to his land. When armies approach the city he can only work at night hauling merchandise out of fear of being conscripted. One time
column6: his son brings home stolen meat. Furious
column7: Wang Lung throws the meat on the ground
column8: not wanting his sons to grow up as thieves. O-Lan
column9: however
column10: calmly picks up the meat and cooks it. When a food riot erupts
column11: Wang Lung is swept up in a mob that is looting a rich man's house and corners the man himself
column12: who fears for his life and gives Wang Lung all his money in order to buy his safety. O-Lan finds a cache of jewels elsewhere in the house and takes them for herself.

column1: Wang Lung uses this money to bring the family home
column2: buy a new ox and farm tools
column3: and hire servants to work the land for him. In time
column4: two more children are born
column5: a twin son and daughter. When he discovers the jewels that O-Lan looted
column6: Wang Lung buys the House of Hwang's remaining land. He later sends his first two sons to school
column7: also apprenticing the second one to a merchant
column8: and retains the third one on the land.

column1: As Wang Lung becomes more prosperous
column2: he buys a concubine named Lotus. O-Lan endures the betrayal of her husband when he takes the only jewels she had asked to keep for herself
column4: so that he can make them into earrings to present to Lotus. O-Lan's health and morale deteriorate
column5: and she eventually dies just after witnessing her first son's wedding. Wang Lung finally appreciates her place in his life as he mourns her passing.

column1: Wang Lung and his family move into town and rent the old House of Hwang. Now an old man

column3: especially between his first and second sons and their wives. Wang Lung's third son runs away to become a soldier. At the end of the novel
column4: Wang Lung overhears his sons planning to sell the land and tries to dissuade them. They say they will do as he wishes
column5: but smile knowingly at each other.|

column13: |Snow Flower and the Secret Fan is a 2005 novel by Lisa See set in nineteenth-century China. In her introduction to the novel
column14: See writes that Lily
column15: the narrator
column16: was born on June 5
column17: 1824—"the fifth day of the sixth month of the third year of the Daoguang Emperor's reign". The novel begins in 1903
column18: when Lily is 80 years old. It continues on to tell the story of her life from birth
column19: childhood
column20: marriage
column21: and old age.  During her lifetime
column22: Lily lives through the reigns of four emperors of the Qing dynasty: Daoguang (1820–1850); Xianfeng (1850–1861); Tongzhi (1861–1875); and Guangxu  (1875–1908).

column1: The University of Southern California China historian Charlotte Furth wrote that Western readers think of Chinese women simply as victims and focus on such problems as footbinding and arranged marriages
column2: but that Lisa See's historical novels "follow the best feminist scholarship on women in the Ming-Qing period by tackling these stereotypes." In Snowflower and the Secret Fan and in Peony in Love
column3: See "asks readers to imagine how a few such women might have found voices of their own within
column4: rather than in opposition to
column5: the Confucian social order
column6: and how they found ways to self-fulfillment without flouting their culture’s fundamental values." The novel received an honorable mention from the Asian/Pacific American Awards for Literature.|

column2: The Broker
column13: |Joel Backman is "the Broker
column14: considered to be one of the most powerful lobbyists in Washington, D.C.. However, Backman's life falls apart when a deal collapses involving a hacked spy satellite that nobody knows about, and he ends up in jail. Six years later, the political wheels have turned and other power-hungry men are eager for Backman's blood. Bargains are made, and after an outgoing disgraced President grants him a full pardon at the behest of the CIA, Backman finds himself spirited out of the prison in the middle of the night, bundled onto a military plane, and flown to Italy to begin a new life. He has a new name and mysterious new friends" who teach him to speak the language and to blend in with the people in Bologna.

column1: However
column2: Backman soon realizes that something is not quite kosher in this new setup
column3: in that he is under constant surveillance. In reality
column4: the CIA is setting him up for professional assassins from China
column5: Israel
column6: Russia
column7: Saudi Arabia and other countries. They intend to sit back and wait to see who kills him in an effort to solve the biggest mystery to hit the US government in decades: the question of who built this seemingly impenetrable and most advanced satellite ever. It turns out to be China; despite having low satellite technology
column8: they stole the information from the US.

column1: Backman barely survives several assassination attempts and manages to establish communication with his son
column2: Neal. He escapes surveillance and returns to his home to contract a new deal with the US government. The CIA is told about the satellite
column3: along with the taking of the satellite's program. In return
column4: they agree to do what they can to get the countries targeting him to back off
column5: though they caution him that some of them will not listen. Backman then covers his escape by pretending that he is resuming his old life
column6: then quietly disappears and presumably returns to Italy.|

The Iliad
column13: |The Iliad (; Ancient Greek: Ἰλιάς
column14: romanized: Iliás
column15: Attic Greek: [iː.li.ás]; sometimes referred to as the Song of Ilion or Song of Ilium) is an ancient Greek epic poem in dactylic hexameter
column16: traditionally attributed to Homer. Usually considered to have been written down circa the 8th century BC
column17: the Iliad is among the oldest extant works of Western literature
column18: along with the Odyssey
column19: another epic poem attributed to Homer
column20: which tells of Odysseus's experiences after the events of the Iliad. In the modern vulgate (the standard accepted version)
column21: the Iliad contains 15
column23: divided into 24 books; it is written in Homeric Greek
column24: a literary amalgam of Ionic Greek and other dialects. It is usually grouped in the Epic Cycle.

column1: Set during the Trojan War
column2: the ten-year siege of the city of Troy (Ilium) by a coalition of Mycenaean Greek states (Achaeans)
column3: it tells of the battles and events during the weeks of a quarrel between King Agamemnon and the warrior Achilles.

column1: Although the story covers only a few weeks in the final year of the war
column2: the Iliad mentions or alludes to many of the Greek legends about the siege; the earlier events
column3: such as the gathering of warriors for the siege
column4: the cause of the war
column5: and related concerns
column6: tend to appear near the beginning. Then the epic narrative takes up events prophesied for the future
column7: such as Achilles's imminent death and the fall of Troy
column8: although the narrative ends before these events take place. However
column9: as these events are prefigured and alluded to more and more vividly
column10: when it reaches an end
column11: the poem has told a more or less complete tale of the Trojan War.|

column2: The Odyssey
column13: |The Odyssey (; Ancient Greek: Ὀδύσσεια
column14: romanized: Odýsseia
column15: Attic Greek: [o.dýs.seː.a]) is one of two major ancient Greek epic poems attributed to Homer. It is one of the oldest extant works of literature still widely read by modern audiences. As with the Iliad
column16: the poem is divided into 24 books. It follows the Greek hero Odysseus
column17: king of Ithaca
column18: and his journey home after the Trojan War. After the war itself
column19: which lasted ten years
column20: his journey lasted for ten additional years
column21: during which time he encountered many perils and all his crew mates were killed. In his absence
column23: and his wife Penelope and son Telemachus had to contend with a group of unruly suitors who were competing for Penelope's hand in marriage.

column1: The Odyssey was originally composed in Homeric Greek in around the 8th or 7th century BCE and
column2: by the mid-6th century BCE
column3: had become part of the Greek literary canon. In antiquity
column4: Homer's authorship of the poem was not questioned
column5: but contemporary scholarship predominantly assumes that the Iliad and the Odyssey were composed independently
column6: and the stories themselves formed as part of a long oral tradition. Given widespread illiteracy
column7: the poem was performed by an aoidos or rhapsode
column8: and more likely to be heard than read.

column1: Crucial themes in the poem include the ideas of nostos (νόστος; "return")
column2: wandering
column4: testing
column5: and omens. Scholars still reflect on the narrative significance of certain groups in the poem
column6: such as women and slaves
column7: who have a more prominent role in the epic than in many other works of ancient literature. This focus is especially remarkable when considered beside the Iliad
column8: which centres the exploits of soldiers and kings during the Trojan War.

column1: The Odyssey is regarded as one of the most significant works of the Western canon. The first English translation of the Odyssey was in the 16th century. Adaptations and re-imaginings continue to be produced across a wide variety of mediums. In 2018
column2: when BBC Culture polled experts around the world to find literature's most enduring narrative

column2: By the River Piedra I Sat Down and Wept
column13: |Paulo Coelho de Souza (
column14: Portuguese: [ˈpawlu kuˈeʎu]; born 24 August 1947) is a Brazilian lyricist and novelist. He is a member of the Brazilian Academy of Letters. His novel The Alchemist has sold more than 150 million copies worldwide and is the all-time best-selling book by a Brazilian writer. He influenced Brazilian rock music through his partnership with the musician Raul Seixas.|

column2: Veronika Decides to Die
column13: |Veronika Decides to Die (Portuguese: Veronika Decide Morrer) is a novel by Paulo Coelho. It tells the story of Veronika
column14: a 24-year-old Slovenian who appears to have everything in life going for her
column15: but who decides to kill herself. This book is partly based on Coelho's experience in various mental institutions (see the biography Confessions of a Pilgrim by Juan Arias)
column16: and deals with the subject of madness. The gist of the message is that "collective madness is called sanity".|

The Peloponnesian War
column13: |The Peloponnesian War (431–404 BC) was an ancient Greek war fought between the Delian League
column14: which was led by Athens
column15: and the Peloponnesian League
column16: which was led by Sparta. Historians have traditionally divided the war into three phases. In the first phase
column17: the Archidamian War
column18: Sparta launched repeated invasions of Attica
column19: while Athens took advantage of its naval supremacy to raid the coast of the Peloponnese and attempt to suppress signs of unrest in its empire. This period of the war was concluded in 421 BC
column20: with the signing of the Peace of Nicias. That treaty
column21: however
column22: was soon undermined by renewed fighting in the Peloponnese. In 415 BC
column23: Athens dispatched a massive expeditionary force to attack Syracuse
column24: Sicily; the attack failed disastrously
column25: with the destruction of the entire force in 413 BC. This ushered in the final phase of the war
column26: generally referred to either as the Decelean War
column27: or the Ionian War. In this phase
column29: now receiving support from the Achaemenid Empire
column30: supported rebellions in Athens's subject states in the Aegean Sea and Ionia
column34: depriving the city of naval supremacy. The destruction of Athens's fleet in the Battle of Aegospotami effectively ended the war
column35: and Athens surrendered in the following year. Corinth and Thebes demanded that Athens should be destroyed and all its citizens should be enslaved

column1: Although the term "Peloponnesian War" was never used by Thucydides
column2: one of the conflict's most important historians
column3: the fact that the term is all but universally used today is a reflection of the Athens-centric sympathies of modern historians. As prominent historian J. B. Bury remarks
column4: the Peloponnesians would have considered it the "Attic War".The Peloponnesian War reshaped the ancient Greek world. On the level of international relations
column5: Athens
column6: the strongest city-state in Greece prior to the war's beginning
column7: was reduced to a state of near-complete subjection
column8: while Sparta became established as the leading power of Greece. The economic costs of the war were felt all across Greece; poverty became widespread in the Peloponnese
column9: while Athens was completely devastated
column10: and never regained its pre-war prosperity. The war also wrought subtler changes to Greek society; the conflict between democratic Athens and oligarchic Sparta
column11: each of which supported friendly political factions within other states
column12: made war a common occurrence in the Greek world.

column1: Ancient Greek warfare
column2: meanwhile
column3: originally a limited and formalized form of conflict
column4: was transformed into an all-out struggle between city-states
column5: complete with atrocities on a large scale. Shattering religious and cultural taboos
column6: devastating vast swathes of countryside
column8: the Peloponnesian War marked the dramatic end to the fifth century BC and the golden age of Greece.The Peloponnesian War was soon followed by the Corinthian War (394–386 BC)
column9: which
column10: although it ended inconclusively
column11: helped Athens regain some of its former greatness.|

Bakkhai
column13: |The play begins before the palace at Thebes
column14: with Dionysus telling the story of his birth and his reasons for visiting the city.  Dionysus explains he is the son of a mortal woman
column15: Semele
column16: and a god
column17: Zeus. Some in Thebes
column18: he notes
column19: don't believe this story. In fact
column20: Semele's sisters—Autonoe
column21: Agave
column22: and Ino—claim it is a lie intended to cover up the fact that Semele became pregnant by some mortal. Dionysus reveals that he has driven the women of the city mad
column23: including his three aunts
column24: and has led them into the mountains to observe his ritual festivities. He has disguised himself as a mortal for the time being
column25: but he plans to vindicate his mother by appearing before all of Thebes as a god
column26: the son of Zeus
column27: and establishing his permanent cult of followers.Dionysus exits to the mountains
column28: and the chorus (composed of the titular Bacchae) enters.  They perform a choral ode in praise of Dionysus. Then Tiresias
column31: the founder and former king of Thebes. The two old men start out to join the revelry in the mountains when Cadmus’ petulant young grandson Pentheus
column33: enters. Disgusted to find the two old men in festival dress
column34: he scolds them and orders his soldiers to arrest anyone engaging in Dionysian worship
column35: including the mysterious "foreigner" who has introduced this worship. Pentheus intends to have him stoned to death.The guards soon return with Dionysus himself in tow.  Pentheus questions him
column36: both skeptical of and fascinated by the Dionysian rites. Dionysus's answers are cryptic. Infuriated
column37: Pentheus has Dionysus taken away and chained to an angry bull in the palace stable. But the god now shows his power. He breaks free and razes the palace with an earthquake and fire.  Dionysus and Pentheus are once again at odds when a herdsman arrives from the top of Mount Cithaeron
column38: where he had been herding his grazing cattle. He reports that he found women on the mountain behaving strangely: wandering the forest
column41: and performing miraculous feats. The herdsmen and the shepherds made a plan to capture one particular celebrant
column42: Pentheus' mother.  But when they jumped out of hiding to grab her
column43: the Bacchae became frenzied and pursued the men. The men escaped
column44: but their cattle were not so fortunate
column45: as the women fell upon the animals
column46: ripping them to shreds with their bare hands.  The women carried on
column47: plundering two villages that were further down the mountain
column49: iron and even babies. When villagers attempted to fight back
column50: the women drove them off using only their ceremonial staffs of fennel. They then returned to the mountain top and washed up

column1: Dionysus
column2: still in disguise
column3: persuades Pentheus to forgo his plan to defeat and massacre the women with an armed force.  He says it would be better first to spy on them
column4: while disguised as a female Maenad to avoid detection. Dressing Pentheus in this fashion
column5: giving him a thyrsus and fawn skins
column6: Dionysus leads him out of the house. At this point
column7: Pentheus seems already crazed by the god's power
column8: as he thinks he sees two suns in the sky
column9: and believes he now has the strength to rip up mountains with his bare hands. He has also begun to see through Dionysus' mortal disguise
column10: perceiving horns coming out of the god's head. They exit to Cithaeron.

column1: A messenger arrives to report that once the party reached Mount Cithaeron
column2: Pentheus wanted to climb an evergreen tree to get a better view and the stranger used divine power to bend down the tall tree and place the king in its highest branches. Then Dionysus
column4: called out to his followers and pointed out the man in the tree. This drove the Maenads wild. Led by Agave
column5: his mother
column6: they forced the trapped Pentheus down from the tree top
column7: ripped off his limbs and his head
column8: and tore his body into pieces.

column1: After the messenger has relayed this news
column2: Agave arrives
column3: carrying her son's bloodied head. In her god-maddened state
column4: she believes it is the head of a mountain lion. She proudly displays it to her father
column5: Cadmus
column6: and is confused when he does not delight in her trophy
column7: but is horrified by it. Agave then calls out for Pentheus to come marvel at her feat
column8: and nail the head above her door so she can show it to all of Thebes. But now the madness begins to wane
column9: and Cadmus forces her to recognize that she has destroyed her own son. As the play ends
column10: the corpse of Pentheus is reassembled as well as is possible
column11: and the royal family is devastated and destroyed. Agave and her sisters are sent into exile

Alcestis
column13: |Alcestis (; Ancient Greek: Ἄλκηστις
column14: Álkēstis) or Alceste
column15: was a princess in Greek mythology
column16: known for her love of her husband. Her life story was told by pseudo-Apollodorus in his Bibliotheca
column17: and a version of her death and return from the dead was also popularized in Euripides's tragedy Alcestis.|

column2: Medea
column13: |In Greek mythology
column14: Medea (; Ancient Greek: Μήδεια
column15: Mēdeia perhaps implying "planner / schemer") is the daughter of King Aeëtes of Colchis
column16: a niece of Circe and the granddaughter of the sun god Helios. Medea figures in the myth of Jason and the Argonauts
column17: appearing in Hesiod's Theogony around 700 BC
column18: but best known from Euripides's tragedy Medea and Apollonius of Rhodes' epic Argonautica. Medea is known in most stories as a sorceress and is often depicted as a priestess of the goddess Hecate.

column1: Medea plays the archetypal role of helper-maiden
column2: aiding Jason in his search for the Golden Fleece by using her magic to save his life out of love. Once he finished his quest
column3: she abandons her native home of Colchis
column4: and flees westwards with Jason
column5: where they eventually settle in Corinth and get married. Euripides' 5th century BC tragedy Medea
column6: depicts the ending of said union with Jason
column7: when after ten years of marriage
column8: Jason abandons her to wed king Creon's daughter Creusa. Medea and her sons by Jason are to be banished from Corinth. In revenge
column9: she murders Creusa with poisoned gifts. Later
column10: she murders her own sons by Jason before fleeing for Athens
column11: where she eventually marries king Aegeus.

column1: What happens afterwards varies according to several accounts. Herodotus in his Histories mentions that she ended up leaving Athens and settling in the Iranian plateau among the Aryans
column2: who subsequently changed their name to the Medes.|

Oresteia
column13: |The Oresteia (Ancient Greek: Ὀρέστεια) is a trilogy of Greek tragedies written by Aeschylus in the 5th century BC
column14: concerning the murder of Agamemnon by Clytemnestra
column15: the murder of Clytemnestra by Orestes
column16: the trial of Orestes
column17: the end of the curse on the House of Atreus and the pacification of the Erinyes. The trilogy—consisting of Agamemnon (Ἀγαμέμνων)
column18: The Libation Bearers (Χοηφóρoι)
column19: and The Eumenides (Εὐμενίδες)—also shows how the Greek gods interacted with the characters and influenced their decisions pertaining to events and disputes. The only extant example of an ancient Greek theatre trilogy
column20: the Oresteia won first prize at the Dionysia festival in 458 BC. The principal themes of the trilogy include the contrast between revenge and justice
column21: as well as the transition from personal vendetta to organized litigation.  Oresteia originally included a satyr play
column23: following the tragic trilogy
column24: but all except a single line of Proteus has been lost.|

column8: the messenger tells him not to worry

Peace
column13: |Peace is a concept of societal friendship and harmony in the absence of hostility and violence. In a social sense
column14: peace is commonly used to mean a lack of conflict (such as war) and freedom from fear of violence between individuals or groups. Throughout history
column15: leaders have used peacemaking and diplomacy to establish a type of behavioral restraint that has resulted in the establishment of regional peace or economic growth through various forms of agreements or peace treaties.  Such behavioral restraint has often resulted in the reduced conflict
column16: greater economic interactivity
column17: and consequently substantial prosperity.

column1: Psychological peace (such as peaceful thinking and emotions) is perhaps less well defined
column2: yet often a necessary precursor to establishing "behavioral peace."  Peaceful behavior sometimes results from a "peaceful inner disposition."  Some have expressed the belief that peace can be initiated with a certain quality of inner tranquility that does not depend upon the uncertainties of daily life. The acquisition of such a "peaceful internal disposition" for oneself and others can contribute to resolving otherwise seemingly irreconcilable competing interests. Peace is not often in the state of excitement although we are happy when excited
column3: but peace is when one's mind is quiet and satisfied.|

column2: Lysistrata
column13: |LYSISTRATA

column1: There are a lot of things about us women
That sadden me
column2: considering how men

column1: See us as rascals.
CALONICE
As indeed we are!
These lines
column2: spoken by the Athenian Lysistrata and her friend Calonice at the beginning of the play
column3: set the scene for the action that follows. Women
column4: as represented by Calonice
column5: are sly hedonists in need of firm guidance and direction. Lysistrata
column6: however
column7: is an extraordinary woman with a large sense of individual and social responsibility. She has convened a meeting of women from various Greek city-states that are at war with each other.  (There is no explanation of how she manages this
column8: but the satirical nature of the play makes this unimportant.)  Soon after she confides in her friend her concerns for the female sex
column9: the women begin arriving.

column1: With support from the Spartan Lampito
column2: Lysistrata persuades the other women to withhold sexual privileges from their menfolk as a means of forcing them to conclude the Peloponnesian War. The women are very reluctant
column3: but the deal is sealed with a solemn oath around a wine bowl
column4: Lysistrata choosing the words and Calonice repeating them on behalf of the other women. It is a long and detailed oath
column5: in which the women abjure all their sexual pleasures
column6: including the Lioness on the Cheese Grater (a sexual position).

column1: Soon after the oath is finished
column2: a cry of triumph is heard from the nearby Acropolis—the old women of Athens have seized control of it at Lysistrata's instigation
column3: since it holds the state treasury
column4: without which the men cannot long continue to fund their war. Lampito goes off to spread the word of revolt
column5: and the other women retreat behind the barred gates of the Acropolis to await the men's response.

column1: A Chorus of Old Men arrives
column2: intent on burning down the gate of the Acropolis if the women do not open up. Encumbered with heavy timbers
column3: inconvenienced with smoke and burdened with old age
column4: they are still making preparations to assault the gate when a Chorus of Old Women arrives
column5: bearing pitchers of water. The Old Women complain about the difficulty they had getting the water
column6: but they are ready for a fight in defence of their younger comrades. Threats are exchanged
column8: and the Old Men are discomfited with a soaking.

column1: The magistrate then arrives with some Scythian Archers (the Athenian version of police constables). He reflects on the hysterical nature of women
column2: their devotion to wine
column4: and exotic cults (such as to Sabazius and Adonis)
column5: but above all he blames men for poor supervision of their womenfolk. He has come for silver from the state treasury to buy oars for the fleet and he instructs his Scythians to begin levering open the gate. However
column6: they are quickly overwhelmed by groups of unruly women with such unruly names as σπερμαγοραιολεκιθολαχανοπώλιδες (seed-market-porridge-vegetable-sellers) and σκοροδοπανδοκευτριαρτοπώλιδες (garlic-innkeeping-bread-sellers).Lysistrata restores order and she allows the magistrate to question her. She explains the frustrations that women feel at a time of war when the men make stupid decisions that affect everyone
column7: and further complains that their wives' opinions are not listened to. She drapes her headdress over him
column8: gives him a basket of wool and tells him that war will be a woman's business from now on. She then explains the pity she feels for young
column9: childless women
column10: ageing at home while the men are away on endless campaigns. When the magistrate points out that men also age
column11: she reminds him that men can marry at any age whereas a woman has only a short time before she is considered too old. She then dresses the magistrate like a corpse for laying out
column12: with a wreath and a fillet
column13: and advises him that he's dead. Outraged at these indignities
column14: he storms off to report the incident to his colleagues
column15: while Lysistrata returns to the Acropolis.

column1: The debate or agon is continued between the Chorus of Old Men and the Chorus of Old Women until Lysistrata returns to the stage with some news—her comrades are desperate for sex and they are beginning to desert on the silliest pretexts (for example
column2: one woman says she has to go home to air her fabrics by spreading them on the bed). After rallying her comrades and restoring their discipline
column3: Lysistrata again returns to the Acropolis to continue waiting for the men's surrender.

column1: A man suddenly appears
column2: desperate for sex. It is Kinesias
column3: the husband of Myrrhine. Lysistrata instructs her to torture him. Myrrhine informs Kinesias that she will have sex with him but only if he promises to end the war. He promptly agrees to these terms and the young couple prepares for sex on the spot. Myrrhine fetches a bed
column4: then a mattress
column5: then a pillow
column6: then a blanket
column8: exasperating her husband with delays until finally disappointing him completely by locking herself in the Acropolis again. The Chorus of Old Men commiserates with the young man in a plaintive song.

column1: A Spartan herald then appears with a large burden (an erection) scarcely hidden inside his tunic and he requests to see the ruling council to arrange peace talks. The magistrate
column2: now also sporting a prodigious burden
column3: laughs at the herald's embarrassing situation but agrees that peace talks should begin.

column1: They go off to fetch the delegates. While they are gone
column2: the Old Women make overtures to the Old Men. The Old Men are content to be comforted and fussed over by the Old Women; thereupon the two Choruses merge
column3: singing and dancing in unison. Peace talks commence and Lysistrata introduces the Spartan and Athenian delegates to a gorgeous young woman called Reconciliation. The delegates cannot take their eyes off the young woman; meanwhile
column4: Lysistrata scolds both sides for past errors of judgment. The delegates briefly squabble over the peace terms
column5: but with Reconciliation before them and the burden of sexual deprivation still heavy upon them
column6: they quickly overcome their differences and retire to the Acropolis for celebrations.  The war is ended.

column1: Another choral song follows.  After a bit of humorous dialogue between tipsy dinner guests
column2: the celebrants all return to the stage for a final round of songs
column3: the men and women dancing together.  All sing a merry song in praise of Athene
column4: goddess of wisdom and chastity
column5: whose citadel provided a refuge for the women during the events of the comedy
column6: and whose implied blessing has brought about a happy ending to the play.|

column2: The Curious Incident of the Dog in the Night-Time
column13: |Christopher John Francis Boone is a 15-year-old boy who has behavioural problems and lives with his father
column14: Ed. He explains in his narration that his mother
column15: Judy
column16: died two years before. Then one day
column17: the boy discovers the dead body of the neighbour's dog
column18: Wellington
column19: speared by a garden fork. Mrs. Shears
column20: the dog's owner
column21: calls the police
column22: and Christopher comes under suspicion. He is arrested
column23: then released with a police caution. He decides to investigate the dog's death. Throughout his adventures
column24: Christopher records his experiences in a book. During his investigation
column25: Christopher meets the elderly Mrs. Alexander
column26: who informs Christopher that his mother had an affair with Mr. Shears.

column1: Ed discovers the book and confiscates it. While searching for the confiscated book
column2: Christopher discovers letters from his mother dated after her supposed death. He is so shocked that he is unable to move. Ed realizes that Christopher has read the letters. He confesses that he had lied about Judy's death; he also admits that he had killed Wellington
column3: after an argument with Mrs. Shears. Christopher decides to run away and live with his mother.

column1: After a long and event-filled journey
column2: evading policemen and feeling ill from the trains and crowds around him
column3: he finally finds his way to the home of his mother and Mr. Shears. Judy is delighted that Christopher has come to her. Mr. Shears does not want Christopher living with them. Very soon after arriving
column4: Christopher wants to return to Swindon in order to take his mathematics A-level. His mother leaves Mr. Shears
column5: their relationship having broken down because of the rejection of Christopher by Mr. Shears. After an argument with Ed
column6: she agrees to let him see Christopher for daily brief visits. Christopher remains terrified of his father and hopes Ed will be imprisoned for killing Wellington.

column1: The story ends with Ed getting Christopher a puppy and promising that he will rebuild trust with Christopher slowly. Christopher asserts that he will take further exams and attend university. He completes his mathematics A-level with top grades. The book ends with Christopher optimistic about his future
column2: having solved the mystery of the murdered dog
column3: gone to London on his own
column4: found his mother
column5: written a book about his adventures
column6: and achieved an A in exams.|

column2: The Night Gardener
column13: |The novel opens in 1985 at the scene of the discovery of a third victim of the "Night Gardener" so called by the homicide investigators
column14: and establishes Cook as the lead investigator with Ramone and Holiday as rookies. All three victims of the killer were found in community gardens
column15: shot in the head after being similarly assaulted.

column1: Twenty years later Holiday has left the force and Ramone has become a homicide detective. Ramone is working with his squad on the murder of Jacqueline Taylor. They manage to arrest and extract a confession from her boyfriend Tyree Williams which is backed by physical evidence. At home Ramone enjoys a happy family life and tries to mentor his son through the prejudices of his new school.
Holiday now works as a chauffeur
column2: drinks in a bar and is unmotivated. One night after cruising
column4: Holiday falls asleep in his car near a community garden. He witnesses some events before sleeping again and awakes to find the body of Asa Johnson with a gunshot wound to the temple. Holiday makes an anonymous call to the police.

column1: Bill "Garloo" Wilkins is the primary investigator on the Johnson case. Ramone becomes involved because of the boy's friendship with his son. He begins to notice similarities to the palindrome murders but says nothing. The Johnson family pressures Ramone to find a suspect. Evidence and the autopsy show a link with the palindrome murders. Wilkins uncovers evidence that Johnson was homosexual on his home computer. Ramone recognises Holiday's voice on the tape of the anonymous call and tracks him down.
Holiday also realises the similarity to the palindrome murders and contacts Cook. Now retired and afflicted by a small stroke
column2: Cook continues to trail the early suspect Reginald Wilson. Wilson went to prison shortly after the last murder in the 80s and Cook still believes Wilson is the "Night Gardener". He is invigorated by the possibility of another chance to prove his theory and eagerly joins Holiday in an unofficial investigation.

column1: Ramone arranges to meet with Cook and Holiday. Holiday is truthful about everything he saw on the night of Johnson's death and Cook tells Ramone about his suspicions over Wilson but it turns out that Wilson has an alibi for the night in question.
The night after the Johnson killing Ramone's partner
column2: Rhonda Willis becomes the primary investigator on a new case
column3: the murder of Jamal White. They find that the same gun was used in the deaths of White and Johnson. Through a tangled chain of connections detectives trace and arrest Aldan "Beano" Tinsley who
column4: under pressure
column5: confesses to finding the gun when walking through the gardens - after Asa Johnson shot himself.

column1: Remembering the number of the patrol car from his night near the gardens
column2: Holiday manages to identify the officer driving as Grady Dunne without Ramone's help. Ramone meets Holiday and tells him that Johnson's death was not related to the palindrome murders. Ramone convinces Holiday to identify Tinsley as the man he saw in the gardens on the night of Johnson's death in order to strengthen the White case because he abused Tinsley's rights in order to get the information he needed. Holiday is surprised to find that Ramone is not as straight as he believed.

column1: Ramone returns to the gardens and finds Asa Johnson's journal hidden near where his body was found. He reads the diary in full and finds that Johnson had a relationship with a man who used the pseudonym "RoboMan". Ramone believes this was Johnson's math teacher Robert Bolton. Ramone resolves to trace the origins of the gun Johnson used
column2: finding it belonged to Terrance Johnson which he remains quiet about. Instead he passes the information about the teacher on to the Morals Unit.

column1: Holiday keeps the information about Johnson's suicide from Cook as he is worried it will demoralise him. Holiday and Cook follow Dunne to the gas station where Wilson works and are excited at the potential connection. They split up and Holiday confronts Dunne and realises that while he is corrupt he was not involved in Johnson's death.  Holiday resolves to tell Cook the truth. Cook follows Wilson and then goes to his home with plans to break in.  Cook approaches the house but becomes suddenly unwell and passes away in his car outside.

Holiday tells Ramone that Cook is missing and eventually finds his body. Holiday moves it to another location to avoid the press saying that Cook was still obsessed with the palindrome case.  Blaming himself for Cook's death
column2: he resolves to break into Wilson's home himself. In an unrelated drug shootout
column4: and in the melee
column5: Brock
column6: Benjamin and Dunne are killed and Henderson flees.

column1: The novel closes with a return to 1985 and the revelation that Wilson was responsible for the palindrome murders
column2: hiding trophies from each victim in his record collection.|

column1: While traveling to Hogwarts on the Hogwarts Express
column2: Harry says he suspects Draco is a Death Eater. Harry eavesdrops on Draco

column13: |A hatchet (from the Old French hachete
column14: a diminutive form of hache
column15: 'axe' of Germanic origin) is a single-handed striking tool with a sharp blade on one side used to cut and split wood
column16: and a hammerhead on the other side.  Hatchets may also be used for hewing when making flattened surfaces on logs; when the hatchet head is optimized for this purpose it is called a hewing hatchet.Although hand axe and hatchet are often used interchangeably
column17: they are not the same thing. A hand axe is essentially a miniature axe with a flat butt or poll on the back side of the head
column18: whereas a hatchet has a hammerhead on the back.Hatchets have a variety of uses
column19: such as tasks normally done by a pocket knife when one is not present. The hatchet can also be used to create fire through sparks and friction. Hatchet throwing is increasing in popularity."Burying the hatchet" is a phrase meaning to make peace
column20: due to the Native American tradition of hiding or putting away a tomahawk when a peace agreement was made.

column1: Hatchet was used to describe a battle-axe in Middle English.|

column2: I am Charlotte Simmons
column13: |I am Charlotte Simmons is the story of college student Charlotte Simmons's first semester-and-a-half at the prestigious Dupont University. A high school graduate from a poverty-stricken rural town
column14: her intelligence and hard work at school have been rewarded with a full scholarship to Dupont.

column1: As Charlotte prepares to say goodbye to her family and leave for college
column2: an event happens at Dupont that will play an important role in her future. Hoyt Thorpe
column3: member of the exclusive and powerful fraternity Saint Ray
column4: and fellow frat brother Vance
column5: stumble upon an unnamed California Republican governor (who was at the college to speak at the school's commencement ceremony) receiving oral sex from a female college student. When the governor's bodyguard spots the two fraternity members
column6: a fight ensues with Hoyt and Vance beating up the bodyguard and fleeing. The story of the night soon spreads across campus

column1: Charlotte arrives at Dupont in the fall. Her roommate is wealthy Beverly
column2: the daughter of the CEO of a huge multinational insurance company. She is obsessed with sex
column3: in particular with members of the school's lacrosse team.

column1: Jojo Johanssen is a white athlete on the college's predominantly black basketball team.  He is struggling to keep his position because the school recently recruited an up-and-coming black freshman player
column2: and the coach wants to bench Jojo in his senior year. This would severely hurt Jojo's chances of playing in "the league" (the NBA).

column1: Jojo enjoys the spoils of being a college athlete
column2: such as using a tutor program to force other students to complete his school assignments. Jojo's "tutor" Adam Gellin is
column4: from a working-class background. Adam writes for the college's independent newspaper and is a member of the "Millennial Mutants
column5:
a group of like-minded intellectuals who oppose the anti-intellectualism and class snobbery they see in their fellow students.
Charlotte and Adam first meet at the university's computer lab, where Adam is to write a paper for Jojo. Charlotte does not back down when Adam insists that he needs the computer more than she does. Adam is instantly smitten.
Charlotte finds herself dealing with the sexual temptations of college life, culminating in her hooking up with Hoyt, who tells Charlotte of catching California's governor receiving oral sex from a college student. He also tells Charlotte he knows that Adam Gellin has begun investigating the incident and how, at the behest of the governor a large Wall Street firm has offered him (Hoyt) a high-paying entry-level job in exchange for his silence. (The firm, Pierce & Pierce, is the name of the one that Sherman McCoy works for in Wolfe's earlier novel, The Bonfire of the Vanities.)
Hoyt and Charlotte attend an important fraternity formal together, after which Hoyt takes full advantage of a drunken Charlotte, seducing her into giving up her virginity to him. The following morning, Charlotte is dumped by Hoyt. She is further humiliated when she returns to campus and discovers that Hoyt's seduction and rejection has been made public via two girls Charlotte had previously befriended. The two cruelly mock Charlotte, both over her poverty-stricken background, and for how she drunkenly lost her virginity.
This drives Charlotte into a depression and eventually into the arms of Adam, who has wanted Charlotte for her beauty, innocence, and intellect since they first met. Charlotte finally emerges from her depression but finds that she has received terrible grades (B, B−, C−, D) for her first semester at Dupont.
As Adam prepares to publish his article, his world collides with Jojo Johanssen's when a paper that Adam wrote for the athlete is accused of being plagiarized. Jojo, who treats Adam as beneath him socially, denies the plagiarism charge and protects the athletic department's perversion of the athlete/tutor program from being exposed.
Jojo has begun to transform himself academically from a stereotypical dumb jock" into a student who takes his academics seriously and even develops an interest in philosophy (partly as a result of Charlotte's influence). Jerome Quat
column6: Jojo's professor

column8: when Adam confesses to having written the paper for Jojo
column9: the professor double-crosses him. He will sacrifice Adam in order to bring down the basketball program
column10: which has circled the wagons to protect Jojo.

column1: This devastates Adam
column2: who breaks down and needs Charlotte to take care of him as he waits to be formally charged with cheating. In the meantime
column3: Adam's article on "The Night of the Skullfuck" is published. The sordid details of sex
column4: violence
column5: bribery
column6: and a high-profile political figure cause it to be picked up by the national media. The governor's Presidential ambitions are potentially ruined
column7: and the job offer/bribe made to Hoyt is revoked
column8: effectively shattering Hoyt's life.

column1: Hoyt now faces a post-graduation judgment day

column3: and a college transcript with such bad grades that will effectively keep him from getting a job as an investment banker. Jojo's and Adam's necks are saved

Tropic of Cancer
column13: |The Tropic of Cancer
column14: which is also referred to as the Northern Tropic
column15: is the most northerly circle of latitude on Earth at which the Sun can be directly overhead. This occurs on the June solstice
column16: when the Northern Hemisphere is tilted toward the Sun to its maximum extent. It also reaches 90 degrees below the horizon at solar midnight on the December Solstice. Using a continuously updated formula
column17: the circle is currently 23°26′11.1″ (or 23.43643°) north of the Equator.

column1: Its Southern Hemisphere counterpart
column2: marking the most southerly position at which the Sun can be directly overhead
column3: is the Tropic of Capricorn. These tropics are two of the five major circles of latitude that mark maps of Earth
column4: the others being the Arctic and Antarctic circles and the Equator. The positions of these two circles of latitude (relative to the Equator) are dictated by the tilt of Earth's axis of rotation relative to the plane of its orbit
column5: and since the tilt changes
column6: the location of these two circles also changes.|

column2: Tropic of Capricorn
column13: |The Tropic of Capricorn (or the Southern Tropic) is the circle of latitude that contains the subsolar point at the December (or southern) solstice. It is thus the southernmost latitude where the Sun can be seen directly overhead. It also reaches 90 degrees below the horizon at solar midnight on the June Solstice. Its northern equivalent is the Tropic of Cancer.

column1: The Tropic of Capricorn is one of the five major circles of latitude marked on maps of Earth. Its latitude is currently 23°26′11.1″ (or 23.43643°) south of the Equator
column2: but it is very gradually moving northward
column3: currently at the rate of 0.47 arcseconds
column4: or 15 metres
column5: per year.

column2: The Portrait of a Lady
column13: |The Portrait of a Lady is a novel by Henry James

column1: The Portrait of a Lady is the story of a spirited young American woman
column2: Isabel Archer
column4: "affronting her destiny
column5:
finds it overwhelming. She inherits a large amount of money and subsequently becomes the victim of Machiavellian scheming by two American expatriates. Like many of James's novels, it is set in Europe, mostly England and Italy. Generally regarded as the masterpiece of James's early period, this novel reflects James's continuing interest in the differences between the New World and the Old, often to the detriment of the former. It also treats in a profound way the themes of personal freedom, responsibility, and betrayal.|
277,Writing,Marguerite Duras,3.75,1571290532,9781571290533,eng,91,778,44,5/6/1999,Brookline Books,|Writing is a medium of human communication that involves the representation of a language with written symbols. Writing systems are not themselves human languages (with the debatable exception of computer languages); they are means of rendering a language into a form that can be reconstructed by other humans separated by time and/or space. While not all languages use a writing system, those with systems of inscriptions can complement and extend capacities of spoken language by enabling the creation of durable forms of speech that can be transmitted across space (e.g., correspondence) and stored over time (e.g., libraries or other public records). It has also been observed that the activity of writing itself can have knowledge-transforming effects, since it allows humans to externalize their thinking in forms that are easier to reflect on, elaborate, reconsider, and revise. Writing relies on many of the same semantic structures as the speech it represents, such as lexicon and syntax, with the added dependency of a system of symbols to represent that language's phonology and morphology. The result of the activity of writing is called a text, and the interpreter or activator of this text is called a reader.As human societies emerged, collective motivations for the development of writing were driven by pragmatic exigencies like keeping history, maintaining culture, codifying knowledge through curricula and lists of texts deemed to contain foundational knowledge (e.g., The Canon of Medicine) or to be artistically exceptional (e.g., a literary canon), organizing and governing societies through the formation of legal systems, census records, contracts, deeds of ownership, taxation, trade agreements, treaties, and so on. Amateur historians, including H.G. Wells, had speculated since the early 20th century on the likely correspondence between the emergence of systems of writing and the development of city-states into empires. As Charles Bazerman explains, the marking of signs on stones
column6: clay
column8: and now digital memories—each more portable and rapidly traveling than the previous—provided means for increasingly coordinated and extended action as well as memory across larger groups of people over time and space." For example
column9: around the 4th millennium BC
column10: the complexity of trade and administration in Mesopotamia outgrew human memory
column11: and writing became a more dependable method of recording and presenting transactions in a permanent form. In both ancient Egypt and Mesoamerica
column13: writing may have evolved through calendric and political necessities for recording historical and environmental events. Further innovations included more uniform
column14: predictable
column15: and widely dispersed legal systems
column16: distribution and discussion of accessible versions of sacred texts
column17: and the origins of modern practices of scientific inquiry and knowledge-consolidation
column18: all largely reliant on portable and easily reproducible forms of inscribed language.

column2: The Phantom Tollbooth: A Children's Play in Two Acts
On Bullshit
column13: |On Bullshit is a 2005 book (originally a 1986 essay) by American philosopher Harry G. Frankfurt which presents a theory of bullshit that defines the concept and analyzes the applications of bullshit in the context of communication.  Frankfurt determines that bullshit is speech intended to persuade without regard for truth.  The liar cares about the truth and attempts to hide it; the bullshitter doesn't care if what they say is true or false
column14: but cares only whether the listener is persuaded. Frankfurt's philosophical analysis of bullshit has been analyzed
column15: criticized and adopted by academics since its publication.|
